title: Macroexpand 2025
text:
Macroexpand 2025 is a pair of Clojure conferences organised by Scicloj. They will focus on two high-priority topics on our journey to make Clojure grow to new fields.
These conferences will follow our our conference-making approach that we ðŸŽ¥ discussed recently and developed around the SciNo Light conference.

title: Proposed Scicloj Conferences for Oct.Â 2025
text:
, deepening our discussions at the Scicoj AI group.
Hi. Following a chat with @**siyoungb** , here is an initial concept for the next conferences we are hoping to organise.

title: Proposed Scicloj Conferences for Oct.Â 2025
text:
Goals

Build new open collaborations around key Clojure growth priorities
Strengthen community support by connecting practitioners
Set a clear target date for projects to reach sharing milestones
Build on lessons learned from scinoj-light-1

title: Proposed Scicloj Conferences for Oct.Â 2025
text:
Timeline
Two online conferences will run in late October. Each spans Friday and Saturday to accommodate different time zones.

Start now - discuss your project ideas with organizers
Until Sep 1st - submit talk proposals
Oct 17-18 - Macroexpand Noj
Oct 24-25 - Macroexpand Deep

title: Proposed Scicloj Conferences for Oct.Â 2025
text:
Agenda
Working titles for the two conferences:

Macroexpand Noj - growing the Noj ecosystem
Focus: helping Noj grow through: 1. Real-world data analysis examples (including follow-ups from scinoj-light-1) 2. Library, theory, and methods documentation 3. New tools and features


Macroexpand Deep - the first Clojure AI conference
Focus: using or building deep learning with Clojure: 1. Building systems with LLMs and embeddings 2. Testing algorithms in specific scenarios 3. Creating and training network architectures 4. Understanding trained networks (mechanistic interpretability) 5. New tools and improvements

title: Proposed Scicloj Conferences for Oct.Â 2025
text:
Speaker Guidelines

Contact us early with project ideas - we can help shape them.
All talks will include clear notes and reproducible code, hosted on Clojure Civitas or Clojure Data Tutorials.

Alternative hosting options available if needed.
Talk proposals should include advanced working drafts.

Team presentations welcome - especially across domains and communities.
If you prefer not to present, you can prepare content for others to present.
Weâ€™re here to help - reach out to brainstorm ideas or find collaborators.

title: Macroexpand 2025
text:
At the Macroexpand conferences, we focus on talks and projects that help Clojure grow.
Our guidelines, based on experience, ensure your work on the talk will be meaningful and fruitful. All talks should cover active projects, ranging from short-term experiments to long-term reports, from analyses to documentation or library improvements. A good talk combines good storytelling with actual progress on your projects.
These guidelines may differ from typical tech conference requirements. If you have any questions, ideas, or requests, please reach out to discuss and find the best approach.

Contact us early with project ideas - we can help shape them and suggest new ones.
All talks must include clear notes and reproducible code, hosted on Clojure Civitas or Clojure Data Tutorials.

If these hosting options do not work for you, letâ€™s discuss alternatives.
Talk proposals should already include self-contained notes as advanced working drafts.
It is highly preferred to create notes which are fully reproducible, including all the data and clear usage instructions.

Each of the two conferences, Macroexpand-Noj & Macroexpand-Deep, has a list of preferred topics, that will be prioritized.
Team presentations are welcome - especially across domains and communities. We encourage collaboration with friends from other fields, including non-programmers.
If you prefer not to present but want to create a project for the conference, you can collaborate with others who will present on your behalf.
Weâ€™re here to help - reach out to brainstorm ideas or find collaborators.

title: Macroexpand 2025
text:
The Macroexpand-Deep conference focuses the development of reserach around AI systems in Clojure.
Here, by the obviously-vague term â€˜AI systemsâ€™, we typically mean systems that involve the composition of deep networks with other components. However, we are open to alternative interpretations, of course.


(Please see the Speakers chapter for guidelines.)

Building systems with LLMs and embeddings
Testing algorithms in specific scenarios
Creating and training network architectures
Understanding trained networks (e.g., mechanistic interpretability)
New tools and improvements
